Definition: Freedom of religion, speech, press, assembly, and petition.
Right to bear arms.
Right to not quarter soldiers (except in times of war as perscribed by law).
Right against unreasonable search and seizure, outlines proper warrents.
Right to due process, against double jeopardy, against self incrimination. Outlines due process. Also has eminent domain.
Right to a speedy public trial by an impartial jury, right to question witnesses, right to council.
Right to a jury in civil trials over $20. Juries cannot be overruled by a court in a manner that doesn't follow common law.
Right against cruel and unusual punishment, right against excessive fines and fees.
Rights given in the Bill of Rights don't block other rights.
Any power not given to the federal government, nor prohibited to the states, is given to the states and the people.
You must be a citizen of a state to sue said state in federal court.
Seperates the race for the president and the vice president.
Ended slavery and involentary bondage in the US (except for in prison).
States cannot deprive rights and due process for all citizens. Responsible for incorporation theory applying the Bill of Rights to states. Later used for birthright citizenship.
Gives universal manhood suffrage.
Instates income tax.
Allows the public to vote for the senate.
Begins prohibition.
Gives women's suffrage.
The lame duck ammendment - moves the start and end of terms to lessen time between election and appointment.
Ends prohibition.
Instates a limit on presidency - either two terms or 10 years.
Gives Washington DC three votes in the presidential election.
Forbids poll taxes.
Outlines succession of the presidency (to the VP) and how a president unable to perform their duties may be removed.
Allows 18 year olds to vote. Instated during the Vietnam War.
Says increases in pay for Congress don't take effect until after the next election.
Establishes judicial review.
Allows the government to stretch to meet the needs of the people. Reaffirms supremacy clause.
Rulled that states could not regulate cherokee land. Ignored by andrew Jackson, which led to the trail of tears.
Only the federal government can regulate interstate trade.
Build up to civil war fugitive slave law. Rules that descendants of slaves could not be citizens.
Segregation deemed legal under "separate but equal" doctrine.
Freedom of speech limitations for national security under the espionage act. "Clear and present danger."
Right to an attorney if accused of a crime or a public defender if you can't afford one.
Right to be read rights when detained.
Ruled segragation violated the 14th amendment.
Internments camps were allowed during a time of war under risk of espionage.
Redefines obscene material, which is not protected under the first amendment.

Term: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke (1978)
Definition: Ruled that universities' racial "quotas" in admission process was unconstitutional. "Affirmative action" to accept more minority applicants was constitutional in some cases.
You do not shed your rights at the schoolhouse gates. Centered around vietnam protests in school.
Right to abortion through 4th amendment right to privacy.
Right to same-sex marriage.
Overruled Roe v. Wade removing the right to abortion.
Ruled that it is unconstitutional for state officials to lead school prayers.
Evidence obtained illegally may not be used in court under the 4th amendment.
Government can punish speech that threatens its existence; anarchy speech implies a national security threat. Freedom of speech applies to the states.
Direct state aid cannot be used to subsidize religious instruction (private religious schools). Aid has to be solely secular and states should gennerally avoid entanglement with religion.
Upheld restrictions on the amount of money an individual can contribute to their campaign but limits on campaign spending is unconstitutional.
Ruled right to interracial marriage.
State ban of contraceptive violated the rights to martial privacy.
Established that the court could not review impeachment, as Article I, Section 3, Constitution gives Senate sole power over all impeachment. Judicial will not review impeachment cases.

Term: To find out who's not here and more importantly who's here.
Definition: Why does Dremousis do attendance?
The absence of political institutions.
A form of government in which power is held by the nobility.
A form of government where power is intensely concentrated in the few. Allows some non-government-conctrolled social and economic institutions.
An economic system characterized by private ownership and free markets.
A set of beliefs characterized by minimizing the role of national government in welfare, supporting traditional values, and a cautious response to change.
A type of government where authority is given to the people as a whole.
A republic in which elected representatives make and enforce laws and policies.
A system of government where people directly make decisions rather than elected officials. Typically found in smaller communities.
A political and religious doctrine asserting that a monarch's power is handed directly by God and is not subject to an earthly authority.
The perspective that society is ruled by a small number of people who exercise power to further their own interests.
The ability of the government to take land with just compensation. Allowed in the 5th amendment.
The political value that everyone is of equal worth.
An institution made to resolve conflicts or allocate benefits. Is the ultimate authority of a society.
Term used more often by government agencies. Describes individuals claiming heritage from a Spanish-speaking country other than Spain.
A comprehensive set of beliefs about the role of government.
A procedure in which citizens can propose a law or amendment.
An ongoing organization that performs functions in a society.
Preferred term for individuals claiming heritage from a Spanish-speaking country other than Spain.
A governmental body responsible for making laws.
A set of beliefs characterized by positive government action for welfare, support for civil rights, and tolerance for political and social change.
A political ideology based on skepticism toward government activities.
Maximizing the freedom of individuals without violating the freedom of other individuals in a society.
The principle that government powers should be limited, usually by institutional checks.
The political theory that in a democracy, government ought to do what the majority of people want.
More than half.
The principle of democracy that the greatest number of citizens should select officials and determine policies.
Rule by the few; a government run by a small group of people for corrupt and self-serving purposes.
A state of peace and security.
A theory viewing politics as conflict among various interest groups. Decision making through bargaining and compromise.
The set of ideas, values, and ways of thinking about government and politics shared by citizens.
The process through which individuals form political attitudes and opinions, often from families and education.
The process of resolving conflicts. Understanding the struggle for power.
Anything subject to ownership.
A procedure for people to vote to remove an official from office.
When decisions on legistlative or constitutional measures are referred from the legistlature to the people.
A form of government in which representatives are elected by the people to make and enforce laws; may retain monarchy in a ceremonial role.
A form of government where soverignty rests with the people rather than a king or monarch.
A theory of politics asserting that individuals form political communities and give up some personal liberty for the protection from a government.
A political ideology based on strong support for economic and social equality.
A form of government that controls all aspects of politicals and social life.
The right of all adults to vote for their representatives.
Opposed the new Constitution in 1787 and in general opposed a strong central goverment.
Allows the public to vote for the Senate.
The principle of government where the actions of one branch are checked by the others.

A political system of independent states that have ultimate authority except for powers they delegate to a central government; a voluntary association of states with few limits on the action of states.

The system of voting for president and vice president where electors from each state and DC cast votes. The number of electors per state is equal to the number of representatives in both chambers of Congress.
Supported the adoption of the Constitution and the creation of a federal union with a strong central government.
A system of government where power is divided by a central and regional governments where both have some domain where their policies are dominant.
The compromise between the New Jersey and Virginia plans for two chambers with one based on population and another having equal representation among states.
The structure of government proposed by James Madison for three branches: legistlative, executive, and judicial.
Rights held to be inherent and not dependent on governments. "Life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness"
Formal approval.
A legistlature consisting of individuals who represent the population.
The principle of dividing powers among different branches of government.
An agreement among individuals to create a government and abide by its rules in order to secure their own rights and welfare.
A group of people occupying a specific area organized under one government.
Asserts the priority of national laws over state laws.
A legistlature with only one chamber. Nebraska is the only state in the Union that features this.
Federal grants to state or local governments for general functional areas such as criminal justice or mental health programs. Groups several categorical grants in one and provides more flexibility.
Federal grants to state or local governments for specific programs. Includes Medicaid, highway construction, unemployment benefits, and housing assistance.
Says increases in pay for Congress don't take effect until after the next election.
Powers held jointly by the national and state governments. Ex. power to tax, borrow funds, establish courts, and charter banks.
A system consisting of a league of independent states with soverign powers. The central government created has limited powers over the states.
The theory that states and the national government should cooperate to solve problems.
The transfer of national or central government powers to state or local government.

A system in which states and the federal government are viewed as two separate and independent spheres which should not interphere with each other. They should not exercise authority in the same areas.

Art. I Sec. 8. Allows the federal government to stretch interpretations of the law to do what is necessary for the government to run. Allowed for the creation of the national bank and department of homeland security.
To surrender an accused or convicted criminal to the authorities of which the person has fled; to return to the jurisdiction of the accusing state.
A system of government in which power is divided into a central government and regional governments or subunits. Each level has some domain in which its policies are dominant.
Federal legistlation that forces states and municipalities to comply with certain rules.
The section of the Constitution requiring states to recognize other states' laws and court decisions.

An agreement between two or more states. May require approval from Congress if it gives an advantage to contracting states relative to other states or the national government. Used to resolve regional problems.
A model of federalism where all policies (the vertical pickets) involve and are supported by all levels of government (the horizontal boards).
The authority to legistlate the protection of health, morals, safety, and welfare of the people. Mostly reserved for states in the US.

Special rights and excemptions provided by the law. States may not discriminate against the citzens of another state. Ex. a student from Oregon attending school at UW is given the same right as Washingtonians to hold a job and travel freely.
Art. VI. The Constitution and federal laws are superior to conflicting state and local laws.
A system of centralized government in which subdivisional governments only exercise powers handed down from the central government.
Either a person's (1) knowledge of the falsity of a defamatory statement or (2) reckless disregard for the truth.
Freedoms that protect indviduals, usually by restraining the actions of governments against individuals.
A test proposed by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes. Free speech can be restricted when there is a clear and present danger to the public order.
Advertising statements. Have increasingly been given 1st amendment protections.
Wrongfully hurting one's good reputation.
Prohibits the federal government from establishing and officially supporting a church. Guarantees separation of church and state.
Illegally obtained evidence cannot be used. Similar to legal principle of fruit of the poisonous tree.
Prohibits the government from constraining the exercise of religion.
An order issued by a judge to restrict news coverage of a trial to protect the accused's right to a fair trial.
The idea that protections in Bill of Rights applies to states through the 14th amendment's due process clause.
Written defamation of a person's character, reputation, business, or property rights.
Restraining an activity before it has occurred. Called censorship when expression is involved.
A public official or celebrity known to the public.
A public statement that is false and harms the good reputation of another made to persons other than the defamed party.
Nonverbal expression of beliefs. Often given substantial protection by the courts.
